abstracts.cdata!:
The achievement of program objectives
            was judged satisfactory. Project sustainability is assessed
            as likely for the reforms as a whole. Overall World Bank
            performance was satisfactory despite the modest results with
            the medium-term components of the program. The overall
            performance of the Borrower was modest. This program was
            highly distinctive in that it was a quick, disbursing,
            single-tranche operation, and one of the first of its kind
            in the region in terms of content. At the same time it was
            negotiated with a government team that changed in
            mid-program. Several lessons can be drawn: The Bank should
            re-examine the instruments it uses for loan programs where
            reforms are politically sensitive and will require a long
            period of gestation. The Bank should in the future wait for
            essential legislative measures to be adopted before taking
            the project to the Board. The Bank must be able to adapt to
            shifts of content and if necessary, revise its expectations
            regarding the degree of Borrower commitment when the
            officials with whom it has to deal change during the course
            of the loan. The Bank should also be more realistic about
            the length of time needed for such a far-reaching reform
            program. Reform of a pension system has to be based on
            actuarial studies and these require access to solid data; in
            this case, these conditions were not fulfilled and the Bank
            needed to allow for the time and cost required to
            reconstitute such data.
